text: hi my name is Ed Steckler I'm an
advertising illustrator in New York City
and I'm here to demonstrate the iPad pro
and before I do that I'm going to show
the equipment that I've been using in
advertising for the last couple years
this is the Wacom Cintiq 13 HD that I'll
be drawing on right now one of the
things that I know about the iPad pro is
that it uses iOS which is not
traditionally a very good software for
real creative drawing one of the things
I don't like about the current set up
that I have is that first of all you
have to bring along a computer to plug
into it's not really that mobile if I
could just walk around Manhattan with an
iPad pro under my arm rather than my
MacBook Pro my Cintiq a million cables
make my life a whole lot easier so I'm
using the iPad pro now for the first
time and I can tell you right away the
pencil feels fantastic I've just opened
up a program called paper I can see
myself drawing with this for fun the pen
is responsive the harder I push that the
thicker a line I get that's exactly I
want I don't know who this guy is but
now I see that in a program I'm using
right now that doesn't seem to have any
layers involved which is a deal-breaker
for a program you have to be able to
draw over other layers you have to be
able to color behind certain layers so
for right now the program I'm using it
says only for goofing around I'm just
going to say not much more than that
now I'm going to start drawing in the
Adobe software it's very hard to go back
it's not very intuitive to start a new
document and I just got an error message
I don't no idea what that's about
yeah this sucks I'm going to try a
sketchbook express quick I don't think
we have the iPad pro version of this
because the line is wonky there's a
weird lag the good thing about this
software is that there are layers so
when you do a rough sketch of anything
you can reduce the opacity of that layer
and you can add a new layer I'll do the
real drawing using that light drawing I
just did as a guide
in a real working environment that's
simply a must you have to be able to
make changes to sketches before you go
to final art I just opened up the
program called procreate which I know is
very popular amongst some artists I know
so far procreate is the best for the
drawing that I've tried so far today and
when you turn the pencil outside you get
that wider line which is just really
cool now I can do layers I can do layers
in procreate my first impression of the
iPad pro is as a fantastic drawing
device it's very responsive and say it
works almost as good as a the Wacom
Cintiq which cost significantly more the
iPad pro is at the very least a place
where you can start drawing the problems
I have so far are software issues such
as layering coloring saving I would say
once iOS figures out the saving
infrastructure so I can easily and
quickly access files locally and have
multiple layered files open at the same
time then iPad pro will definitely be a
viable alternative to what's out there
in the market
